thread.title: Portland police to donate nearly 100-year-old knife to National World War I Museum
thread.title_full: Portland police to donate nearly 100-year-old knife to National World War I Museum | OregonLive.com

author: Maxine Bernstein | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Portland police to donate nearly 100-year-old knife to National World War I Museum
text:
A nearly 100-year-old trench knife that Portland police seized from a suspected drug house in 1997 will be donated to the National World War I Museum and Memorial if City Council members give their nod Wednesday.
The knife â€“ which has a double-edged blade, and knuckle guard handle - has "1918" inscribed on it. Troops in the first World War used it during close-quarter trench warfare to not only stab but also bludgeon enemies with the handle, according to military historians.
The Police Bureau tries to return evidence to its rightful owner, but police couldn't determine who owned the knife, said Ty Routley, manager of the property evidence warehouse.
Officers found it in a home where several people were living among many other items, including guns, tools, fishing equipment, money and drugs.
The person arrested in the case is a convicted felon who couldn't get the knife back even if he had owned it, Routley said.
"Instead of throwing it away, someone saw the date on it and suggested it be donated,'' Routley said. "When we discovered how old it was, someone Googled and found this museum. We have donated historically significant items in the past and thought this one was a good candidate as well.''
Sometimes the bureau auctions off surplus property that no one claims and the money goes back to the bureau's general fund, Routley said.
The National World War I Museum and Memorial in Kansas City, Mo., has worked with other police departments to preserve historical objects. Its website shows images of paintings, uniforms, gas masks, medals and other memorabilia from all nations that were involved in World War I.
The nonprofit museum has been collecting property since 1920. Donated items are used by researchers to better understand the conditions and impact of the war and remain part of the museum's collection, according to the museum's website.
In fact, the museum is looking for any of these items: a European U-boat and navy uniforms, state and county personnel rosters and American women's military uniforms.
